Strong track record of implementing AWS services in a variety of distributed computing environments (Design and implementation experience and Cloud Networking). Strong experience on AWS Infrastructure services (EC2, ELB, RDS, Route53, S3, vpc, vpn, tgw, cloudwatch, cloudtrail, eventbridge, etc. Large scale implementation and migration experience of Data Center to Cloud Infrastructure automation through DevOps scripting (Ansible, Shell, Python, Ruby, PowerShell) Hands on experience in terraform IaC deployments. ğŸš€ My First Azure DevOps Project â€“ Migrating GitHub CI Pipelines to Azure Pipelines!For the past few months, Iâ€™ve been skilling up in DevOps, learning the ins and outs of CI/CD, cloud automation, and infrastructure as code. And today, Iâ€™m excited to share a milestoneâ€”completing my first Azure DevOps project! ğŸ‰This project involved migrating a Voting Appâ€™s CI pipeline from GitHub to Azure Pipelines. While the concept seemed straightforward, implementing it hands-on brought some unexpected challenges (and valuable lessons)!ğŸ”¹ Project OverviewThe Voting App consists of multiple microservices working together:âœ… A Python-based voting serviceâœ… A Redis cache for managing votesâœ… A .NET worker that processes the votesâœ… A PostgreSQL database for storing resultsâœ… A Node.js result service to display the outcomeğŸš§ Challenges I Faced & Lessons LearnedLike any DevOps project, things didnâ€™t go smoothly on the first try! Here are a few errors I encountered and what I learned:âŒ Docker Build FailuresğŸ”¹ Error: â€œThe process â€˜/usr/bin/dockerâ€™ failed with exit code 1.â€ğŸ”¹ Cause: A required argument wasnâ€™t passed in the Dockerfile of the main branch in the cloned repository.ğŸ”¹ Fix: Updated the Dockerfile to ensure all required arguments were properly defined.âŒ YAML Indentation ErrorsğŸ”¹ Problem: Pipelines failed due to incorrect indentation in the azure-pipelines.yml file.ğŸ”¹ Fix: Carefully corrected the YAML structure, ensuring proper indentation and syntax. Lesson learnedâ€”YAML is super picky!At first, these errors felt frustrating, but debugging them taught me more than any tutorial ever could.ğŸ¯ Key TakeawayThe best way to learn DevOps is to get hands-on, break things, and fix them! This project helped me gain deeper insights into CI/CD automation, YAML syntax, Docker builds, and Azure Pipelinesâ€”skills that are critical for any DevOps Engineer.ğŸ™ A Huge Thanks!A special shoutout to Abhishek Veeramalla explaining DevOps concepts in such a simple and clear way! His content has been incredibly helpful throughout my learning journey. ğŸ™ŒğŸ“¸ Attaching some screenshots of what went wrong and the end result of pipelines running.Excited to explore more projects and learn more. hashtag#Azure hashtag#Azuredevops hashtag#devops hashtag#CICD hashtag#Devopsjourney

ğŸš€ My First Azure DevOps Project â€“ Migrating GitHub CI Pipelines to Azure Pipelines!For the past few months, Iâ€™ve been skilling up in DevOps, learning the ins and outs of CI/CD, cloud automation, and infrastructure as code. And today, Iâ€™m excited to share a milestoneâ€”completing my first Azure DevOps project! ğŸ‰This project involved migrating a Voting Appâ€™s CI pipeline from GitHub to Azure Pipelines. While the concept seemed straightforward, implementing it hands-on brought some unexpected challenges (and valuable lessons)!ğŸ”¹ Project OverviewThe Voting App consists of multiple microservices working together:âœ… A Python-based voting serviceâœ… A Redis cache for managing votesâœ… A .NET worker that processes the votesâœ… A PostgreSQL database for storing resultsâœ… A Node.js result service to display the outcomeğŸš§ Challenges I Faced & Lessons LearnedLike any DevOps project, things didnâ€™t go smoothly on the first try! Here are a few errors I encountered and what I learned:âŒ Docker Build FailuresğŸ”¹ Error: â€œThe process â€˜/usr/bin/dockerâ€™ failed with exit code 1.â€ğŸ”¹ Cause: A required argument wasnâ€™t passed in the Dockerfile of the main branch in the cloned repository.ğŸ”¹ Fix: Updated the Dockerfile to ensure all required arguments were properly defined.âŒ YAML Indentation ErrorsğŸ”¹ Problem: Pipelines failed due to incorrect indentation in the azure-pipelines.yml file.ğŸ”¹ Fix: Carefully corrected the YAML structure, ensuring proper indentation and syntax. Lesson learnedâ€”YAML is super picky!At first, these errors felt frustrating, but debugging them taught me more than any tutorial ever could.ğŸ¯ Key TakeawayThe best way to learn DevOps is to get hands-on, break things, and fix them! Requisition Name: AWS Network Cloud Infra EngineerDuration: 12+ months Services Location: TX/Dallas Acceptance Criteria:Onsite workMust be willing to work on our W2H1 Transfers are welcome bob@vinsari.com Description Of Services:AWS Cloud Engineer with networkingÂ skillset What You will need (Qualifications) Atleast 3+ years of experience in AWS with hands-on contribution in DevOps engineering. Strong track record of implementing AWS services in a variety of distributed computing environments (Design and implementation experience and Cloud Networking). Strong experience on AWS Infrastructure services (EC2, ELB, RDS, Route53, S3, vpc, vpn, tgw, cloudwatch, cloudtrail, eventbridge, etc. Large scale implementation and migration experience of Data Center to Cloud Infrastructure automation through DevOps scripting (Ansible, Shell, Python, Ruby, PowerShell) Hands on experience in terraform IaC deployments. Palo Alto & Panaroma Skillset requirements:- Design and architect Palo Alto firewall solutions for AWS cloud-based infrastructures based on business requirements and security best practices. Ability to independently deploy Palo Alto firewalls & Panorama in cloud environments using IaC automation, ensuring proper network segmentation and security zones. Develop and enforce security policies, including threat prevention, URL filtering, application control, and user identification. Ability to Integrate Panorama with other security tools and systems, such as SIEM platforms, to enhance threat detection and response capabilities. Palo Alto Networks certifications (e.g., PCNSA, PCNSE) are highly desirable. ğŸš€ My First Azure DevOps Project â€“ Migrating GitHub CI Pipelines to Azure Pipelines!For the past few months, Iâ€™ve been skilling up in DevOps, learning the ins and outs of CI/CD, cloud automation, and infrastructure as code. And today, Iâ€™m excited to share a milestoneâ€”completing my first Azure DevOps project! ğŸ‰This project involved migrating a Voting Appâ€™s CI pipeline from GitHub to Azure Pipelines. While the concept seemed straightforward, implementing it hands-on brought some unexpected challenges (and valuable lessons)!ğŸ”¹ Project OverviewThe Voting App consists of multiple microservices working together:âœ… A Python-based voting serviceâœ… A Redis cache for managing votesâœ… A .NET worker that processes the votesâœ… A PostgreSQL database for storing resultsâœ… A Node.js result service to display the outcomeğŸš§ Challenges I Faced & Lessons LearnedLike any DevOps project, things didnâ€™t go smoothly on the first try! Here are a few errors I encountered and what I learned:âŒ Docker Build FailuresğŸ”¹ Error: â€œThe process â€˜/usr/bin/dockerâ€™ failed with exit code 1.â€ğŸ”¹ Cause: A required argument wasnâ€™t passed in the Dockerfile of the main branch in the cloned repository.ğŸ”¹ Fix: Updated the Dockerfile to ensure all required arguments were properly defined.âŒ YAML Indentation ErrorsğŸ”¹ Problem: Pipelines failed due to incorrect indentation in the azure-pipelines.yml file.ğŸ”¹ Fix: Carefully corrected the YAML structure, ensuring proper indentation and syntax. Strong track record of implementing AWS services in a variety of distributed computing environments (Design and implementation experience and Cloud Networking). Strong experience on AWS Infrastructure services (EC2, ELB, RDS, Route53, S3, vpc, vpn, tgw, cloudwatch, cloudtrail, eventbridge, etc. Large scale implementation and migration experience of Data Center to Cloud Infrastructure automation through DevOps scripting (Ansible, Shell, Python, Ruby, PowerShell) Hands on experience in terraform IaC deployments. ğŸš€ My First Azure DevOps Project â€“ Migrating GitHub CI Pipelines to Azure Pipelines!For the past few months, Iâ€™ve been skilling up in DevOps, learning the ins and outs of CI/CD, cloud automation, and infrastructure as code. And today, Iâ€™m excited to share a milestoneâ€”completing my first Azure DevOps project! ğŸ‰This project involved migrating a Voting Appâ€™s CI pipeline from GitHub to Azure Pipelines. While the concept seemed straightforward, implementing it hands-on brought some unexpected challenges (and valuable lessons)!ğŸ”¹ Project OverviewThe Voting App consists of multiple microservices working together:âœ… A Python-based voting serviceâœ… A Redis cache for managing votesâœ… A .NET worker that processes the votesâœ… A PostgreSQL database for storing resultsâœ… A Node.js result service to display the outcomeğŸš§ Challenges I Faced & Lessons LearnedLike any DevOps project, things didnâ€™t go smoothly on the first try! Here are a few errors I encountered and what I learned:âŒ Docker Build FailuresğŸ”¹ Error: â€œThe process â€˜/usr/bin/dockerâ€™ failed with exit code 1.â€ğŸ”¹ Cause: A required argument wasnâ€™t passed in the Dockerfile of the main branch in the cloned repository.ğŸ”¹ Fix: Updated the Dockerfile to ensure all required arguments were properly defined.âŒ YAML Indentation ErrorsğŸ”¹ Problem: Pipelines failed due to incorrect indentation in the azure-pipelines.yml file.ğŸ”¹ Fix: Carefully corrected the YAML structure, ensuring proper indentation and syntax. Lesson learnedâ€”YAML is super picky!At first, these errors felt frustrating, but debugging them taught me more than any tutorial ever could.ğŸ¯ Key TakeawayThe best way to learn DevOps is to get hands-on, break things, and fix them! This project helped me gain deeper insights into CI/CD automation, YAML syntax, Docker builds, and Azure Pipelinesâ€”skills that are critical for any DevOps Engineer.ğŸ™ A Huge Thanks!A special shoutout to Abhishek Veeramalla explaining DevOps concepts in such a simple and clear way! His content has been incredibly helpful throughout my learning journey. ğŸ™ŒğŸ“¸ Attaching some screenshots of what went wrong and the end result of pipelines running.Excited to explore more projects and learn more. hashtag#Azure hashtag#Azuredevops hashtag#devops hashtag#CICD hashtag#Devopsjourney

Strong track record of implementing AWS services in a variety of distributed computing environments (Design and implementation experience and Cloud Networking). Strong experience on AWS Infrastructure services (EC2, ELB, RDS, Route53, S3, vpc, vpn, tgw, cloudwatch, cloudtrail, eventbridge, etc. Large scale implementation and migration experience of Data Center to Cloud Infrastructure automation through DevOps scripting (Ansible, Shell, Python, Ruby, PowerShell) Hands on experience in terraform IaC deployments. ğŸš€ My First Azure DevOps Project â€“ Migrating GitHub CI Pipelines to Azure Pipelines!For the past few months, Iâ€™ve been skilling up in DevOps, learning the ins and outs of CI/CD, cloud automation, and infrastructure as code. And today, Iâ€™m excited to share a milestoneâ€”completing my first Azure DevOps project! ğŸ‰This project involved migrating a Voting Appâ€™s CI pipeline from GitHub to Azure Pipelines. While the concept seemed straightforward, implementing it hands-on brought some unexpected challenges (and valuable lessons)!ğŸ”¹ Project OverviewThe Voting App consists of multiple microservices working together:âœ… A Python-based voting serviceâœ… A Redis cache for managing votesâœ… A .NET worker that processes the votesâœ… A PostgreSQL database for storing resultsâœ… A Node.js result service to display the outcomeğŸš§ Challenges I Faced & Lessons LearnedLike any DevOps project, things didnâ€™t go smoothly on the first try! Here are a few errors I encountered and what I learned:âŒ Docker Build FailuresğŸ”¹ Error: â€œThe process â€˜/usr/bin/dockerâ€™ failed with exit code 1.â€ğŸ”¹ Cause: A required argument wasnâ€™t passed in the Dockerfile of the main branch in the cloned repository.ğŸ”¹ Fix: Updated the Dockerfile to ensure all required arguments were properly defined.âŒ YAML Indentation ErrorsğŸ”¹ Problem: Pipelines failed due to incorrect indentation in the azure-pipelines.yml file.ğŸ”¹ Fix: Carefully corrected the YAML structure, ensuring proper indentation and syntax. Lesson learnedâ€”YAML is super picky!At first, these errors felt frustrating, but debugging them taught me more than any tutorial ever could.ğŸ¯ Key TakeawayThe best way to learn DevOps is to get hands-on, break things, and fix them! This project helped me gain deeper insights into CI/CD automation, YAML syntax, Docker builds, and Azure Pipelinesâ€”skills that are critical for any DevOps Engineer.ğŸ™ A Huge Thanks!A special shoutout to Abhishek Veeramalla explaining DevOps concepts in such a simple and clear way! His content has been incredibly helpful throughout my learning journey. ğŸ™ŒğŸ“¸ Attaching some screenshots of what went wrong and the end result of pipelines running.Excited to explore more projects and learn more. hashtag#Azure hashtag#Azuredevops hashtag#devops hashtag#CICD hashtag#Devopsjourney

ğŸš€ My First Azure DevOps Project â€“ Migrating GitHub CI Pipelines to Azure Pipelines!For the past few months, Iâ€™ve been skilling up in DevOps, learning the ins and outs of CI/CD, cloud automation, and infrastructure as code. And today, Iâ€™m excited to share a milestoneâ€”completing my first Azure DevOps project! ğŸ‰This project involved migrating a Voting Appâ€™s CI pipeline from GitHub to Azure Pipelines. While the concept seemed straightforward, implementing it hands-on brought some unexpected challenges (and valuable lessons)!ğŸ”¹ Project OverviewThe Voting App consists of multiple microservices working together:âœ… A Python-based voting serviceâœ… A Redis cache for managing votesâœ… A .NET worker that processes the votesâœ… A PostgreSQL database for storing resultsâœ… A Node.js result service to display the outcomeğŸš§ Challenges I Faced & Lessons LearnedLike any DevOps project, things didnâ€™t go smoothly on the first try! Here are a few errors I encountered and what I learned:âŒ Docker Build FailuresğŸ”¹ Error: â€œThe process â€˜/usr/bin/dockerâ€™ failed with exit code 1.â€ğŸ”¹ Cause: A required argument wasnâ€™t passed in the Dockerfile of the main branch in the cloned repository.ğŸ”¹ Fix: Updated the Dockerfile to ensure all required arguments were properly defined.âŒ YAML Indentation ErrorsğŸ”¹ Problem: Pipelines failed due to incorrect indentation in the azure-pipelines.yml file.ğŸ”¹ Fix: Carefully corrected the YAML structure, ensuring proper indentation and syntax. Lesson learnedâ€”YAML is super picky!At first, these errors felt frustrating, but debugging them taught me more than any tutorial ever could.ğŸ¯ Key TakeawayThe best way to learn DevOps is to get hands-on, break things, and fix them! ğŸš€ My First Azure DevOps Project â€“ Migrating GitHub CI Pipelines to Azure Pipelines!For the past few months, Iâ€™ve been skilling up in DevOps, learning the ins and outs of CI/CD, cloud automation, and infrastructure as code. And today, Iâ€™m excited to share a milestoneâ€”completing my first Azure DevOps project! ğŸ‰This project involved migrating a Voting Appâ€™s CI pipeline from GitHub to Azure Pipelines. While the concept seemed straightforward, implementing it hands-on brought some unexpected challenges (and valuable lessons)!ğŸ”¹ Project OverviewThe Voting App consists of multiple microservices working together:âœ… A Python-based voting serviceâœ… A Redis cache for managing votesâœ… A .NET worker that processes the votesâœ… A PostgreSQL database for storing resultsâœ… A Node.js result service to display the outcomeğŸš§ Challenges I Faced & Lessons LearnedLike any DevOps project, things didnâ€™t go smoothly on the first try! Here are a few errors I encountered and what I learned:âŒ Docker Build FailuresğŸ”¹ Error: â€œThe process â€˜/usr/bin/dockerâ€™ failed with exit code 1.â€ğŸ”¹ Cause: A required argument wasnâ€™t passed in the Dockerfile of the main branch in the cloned repository.ğŸ”¹ Fix: Updated the Dockerfile to ensure all required arguments were properly defined.âŒ YAML Indentation ErrorsğŸ”¹ Problem: Pipelines failed due to incorrect indentation in the azure-pipelines.yml file.ğŸ”¹ Fix: Carefully corrected the YAML structure, ensuring proper indentation and syntax. Lesson learnedâ€”YAML is super picky!At first, these errors felt frustrating, but debugging them taught me more than any tutorial ever could.ğŸ¯ Key TakeawayThe best way to learn DevOps is to get hands-on, break things, and fix them! This project helped me gain deeper insights into CI/CD automation, YAML syntax, Docker builds, and Azure Pipelinesâ€”skills that are critical for any DevOps Engineer.ğŸ™ A Huge Thanks!A special shoutout to Abhishek Veeramalla explaining DevOps concepts in such a simple and clear way! His content has been incredibly helpful throughout my learning journey. ğŸ™ŒğŸ“¸ Attaching some screenshots of what went wrong and the end result of pipelines running.Excited to explore more projects and learn more. hashtag#Azure hashtag#Azuredevops hashtag#devops hashtag#CICD hashtag#Devopsjourney

ğŸš€ My First Azure DevOps Project â€“ Migrating GitHub CI Pipelines to Azure Pipelines!For the past few months, Iâ€™ve been skilling up in DevOps, learning the ins and outs of CI/CD, cloud automation, and infrastructure as code. And today, Iâ€™m excited to share a milestoneâ€”completing my first Azure DevOps project! ğŸ‰This project involved migrating a Voting Appâ€™s CI pipeline from GitHub to Azure Pipelines. While the concept seemed straightforward, implementing it hands-on brought some unexpected challenges (and valuable lessons)!ğŸ”¹ Project OverviewThe Voting App consists of multiple microservices working together:âœ… A Python-based voting serviceâœ… A Redis cache for managing votesâœ… A .NET worker that processes the votesâœ… A PostgreSQL database for storing resultsâœ… A Node.js result service to display the outcomeğŸš§ Challenges I Faced & Lessons LearnedLike any DevOps project, things didnâ€™t go smoothly on the first try! Here are a few errors I encountered and what I learned:âŒ Docker Build FailuresğŸ”¹ Error: â€œThe process â€˜/usr/bin/dockerâ€™ failed with exit code 1.â€ğŸ”¹ Cause: A required argument wasnâ€™t passed in the Dockerfile of the main branch in the cloned repository.ğŸ”¹ Fix: Updated the Dockerfile to ensure all required arguments were properly defined.âŒ YAML Indentation ErrorsğŸ”¹ Problem: Pipelines failed due to incorrect indentation in the azure-pipelines.yml file.ğŸ”¹ Fix: Carefully corrected the YAML structure, ensuring proper indentation and syntax. Lesson learnedâ€”YAML is super picky!At first, these errors felt frustrating, but debugging them taught me more than any tutorial ever could.ğŸ¯ Key TakeawayThe best way to learn DevOps is to get hands-on, break things, and fix them! This project helped me gain deeper insights into CI/CD automation, YAML syntax, Docker builds, and Azure Pipelinesâ€”skills that are critical for any DevOps Engineer.ğŸ™ A Huge Thanks!A special shoutout to Abhishek Veeramalla explaining DevOps concepts in such a simple and clear way! His content has been incredibly helpful throughout my learning journey. ğŸ™ŒğŸ“¸ Attaching some screenshots of what went wrong and the end result of pipelines running.Excited to explore more projects and learn more. hashtag#Azure hashtag#Azuredevops hashtag#devops hashtag#CICD hashtag#Devopsjourney

Requisition Name: AWS Network Cloud Infra EngineerDuration: 12+ months Services Location: TX/Dallas Acceptance Criteria:Onsite workMust be willing to work on our W2H1 Transfers are welcome bob@vinsari.com Description Of Services:AWS Cloud Engineer with networkingÂ skillset What You will need (Qualifications) Atleast 3+ years of experience in AWS with hands-on contribution in DevOps engineering. Strong track record of implementing AWS services in a variety of distributed computing environments (Design and implementation experience and Cloud Networking). Strong experience on AWS Infrastructure services (EC2, ELB, RDS, Route53, S3, vpc, vpn, tgw, cloudwatch, cloudtrail, eventbridge, etc. Large scale implementation and migration experience of Data Center to Cloud Infrastructure automation through DevOps scripting (Ansible, Shell, Python, Ruby, PowerShell) Hands on experience in terraform IaC deployments. Strong Experience in building CI/CD (Gitlab, Jenkins) and deployment automation. Good practical Linux / Windows-based systems administration skills in a Cloud or Virtualized environment Experience working on FedRamp compliant projects is a plus. Palo Alto & Panaroma Skillset requirements:- Design and architect Palo Alto firewall solutions for AWS cloud-based infrastructures based on business requirements and security best practices. Ability to independently deploy Palo Alto firewalls & Panorama in cloud environments using IaC automation, ensuring proper network segmentation and security zones. Strong hands-on experience using Panorama to configure security policies, NAT rules, VPN tunnels, and other firewall settings to protect cloud assets. Implement high availability and failover configurations for firewall devices. Develop and enforce security policies, including threat prevention, URL filtering, application control, and user identification. ğŸš€ My First Azure DevOps Project â€“ Migrating GitHub CI Pipelines to Azure Pipelines!For the past few months, Iâ€™ve been skilling up in DevOps, learning the ins and outs of CI/CD, cloud automation, and infrastructure as code. And today, Iâ€™m excited to share a milestoneâ€”completing my first Azure DevOps project! ğŸ‰This project involved migrating a Voting Appâ€™s CI pipeline from GitHub to Azure Pipelines. While the concept seemed straightforward, implementing it hands-on brought some unexpected challenges (and valuable lessons)!ğŸ”¹ Project OverviewThe Voting App consists of multiple microservices working together:âœ… A Python-based voting serviceâœ… A Redis cache for managing votesâœ… A .NET worker that processes the votesâœ… A PostgreSQL database for storing resultsâœ… A Node.js result service to display the outcomeğŸš§ Challenges I Faced & Lessons LearnedLike any DevOps project, things didnâ€™t go smoothly on the first try! Here are a few errors I encountered and what I learned:âŒ Docker Build FailuresğŸ”¹ Error: â€œThe process â€˜/usr/bin/dockerâ€™ failed with exit code 1.â€ğŸ”¹ Cause: A required argument wasnâ€™t passed in the Dockerfile of the main branch in the cloned repository.ğŸ”¹ Fix: Updated the Dockerfile to ensure all required arguments were properly defined.âŒ YAML Indentation ErrorsğŸ”¹ Problem: Pipelines failed due to incorrect indentation in the azure-pipelines.yml file.ğŸ”¹ Fix: Carefully corrected the YAML structure, ensuring proper indentation and syntax. Lesson learnedâ€”YAML is super picky!At first, these errors felt frustrating, but debugging them taught me more than any tutorial ever could.ğŸ¯ Key TakeawayThe best way to learn DevOps is to get hands-on, break things, and fix them! This project helped me gain deeper insights into CI/CD automation, YAML syntax, Docker builds, and Azure Pipelinesâ€”skills that are critical for any DevOps Engineer.ğŸ™ A Huge Thanks!A special shoutout to Abhishek Veeramalla explaining DevOps concepts in such a simple and clear way! His content has been incredibly helpful throughout my learning journey. ğŸ™ŒğŸ“¸ Attaching some screenshots of what went wrong and the end result of pipelines running.Excited to explore more projects and learn more. hashtag#Azure hashtag#Azuredevops hashtag#devops hashtag#CICD hashtag#Devopsjourney
